questions.question: In an emergency requiring the use of an ELT, it should be turned on

answers.2: at the ETA in the flight plan.
answers.3: for the first five minutes of each hour UTC.
answers.4: during daylight hours only to conserve the battery.

references: TC AIM-SAR - ELT Operating Instructions (Emergency Use)

questions.question: An aircraft’s 121.5 MHz ELT may be switched to transmit for test purposes anytime

answers.2: during the first 5 minutes of any hour UTC.
answers.3: following a component or battery change.
answers.4: prior to flight and listening on 121.5 MHz.

questions.question: Before shutting down you can verify that the aircraft’s ELT is not transmitting by

answers.1: checking that the ELT switch is in the off position.
answers.2: listening on 121.5 MHz for a signal.
answers.3: ensuring that the master switch is off.
answers.4: checking the ELT visual warning light.

references: TC AIM-SAR - ELT Operating Instructions (Normal Use)

questions.question: All accidental ELT activations should be reported to the
references: TC AIM-SAR - Accidental ELT Transmissions, CARs 605.40

questions.question: When an aircraft engine is left running on the ground and no person remains onboard, the aircraft’s movement must be restricted and

answers.1: it must remain in sight of the pilot at all times.
answers.2: it must not be left unattended.
answers.3: its gross weight must be below 4,409 LB (2,000 kg).
answers.4: its control locks must be installed.

references: CARs 602.10 - Starting and Ground Running of Aircraft Engines

questions.question: When confronted with an approaching thunderstorm, a take-off or landing

answers.1: should be avoided as a sudden wind shift or low level turbulence could cause a loss of control.
answers.2: is safe if you can see under the thunderstorm through to the other side.
answers.3: should be avoided unless the take-off can be made away from the thunderstorm.
answers.4: is safe if the thunderstorm is regarded as light.

references: TC AIM-AIR - Flight Ops Near Thunderstorms / Considerations

questions.question: An isolated thunderstorm is in close proximity to your aerodrome of intended landing. You should

answers.1: land giving due consideration to wind shear on final approach.
answers.2: hold over a known point clear of the thunderstorm until it is well past the aerodrome.
answers.4: add one-half the wind gust factor to the recommended landing speed and land.

references: TC AIM-AIR - Flight Ops Near Thunderstorms / Considerations

questions.question: ATC advises that simultaneous operations are in progress at an airport. Pilots could expect a clearance to

answers.1: take-off over top of an aircraft on an intersecting runway.
answers.2: take-off on a specified parallel runway.
answers.3: land and hold short of an intersecting runway.
answers.4: land on a specified parallel runway.

references: TC AIM-RAC - Operations on Intersecting Runways

questions.question: When issued a clearance to land and hold short of an intersecting runway, pilots

answers.1: shall comply regardless of the circumstances.
answers.2: may taxi across the intersection after the departing or arriving aircraft has cleared their path.
answers.3: who inadvertently go through the intersection should immediately do a 180° turn and backtrack to the hold position.
answers.4: should immediately inform ATC if they are unable to comply.

references: TC AIM-RAC - Operations on Intersecting Runways
